title: Gibson, Kidman lead record Aust Oscar pack - 9news.com.au

organizations.name: academy of motion picture arts and sciences

text:
Gibson, Kidman lead record Aust Oscar pack By AAP 
In the dead of night while most of Los Angeles was sleeping, Mel Gibson was up and excitedly tapping away on his phone. 
It was 3am on January 24 and he was trading text messages with Bill Mechanic, his equally excited Hacksaw Ridge producer. 
The Hollywood veterans could not sleep because 2.5 hours later the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences would announce its Oscar nominees and the results would be significant for Gibson not just because they are the pinnacle for any filmmaker, but a nod or a snub would reflect his standing in Hollywood. 
"We were texting back and forth and sort of preparing for maybe being disappointed again," Mechanic told AAP. 
There was only glee. 
Gibson received his directing nomination for Hacksaw Ridge and on Sunday (Monday 12.30pm AEDT) he will lead a record number of Australians - 14 nominees - at the 89th Academy Awards. 
Hacksaw Ridge picked up six nominations, including a best picture nod. 
Another Australian production, Lion, also received six nods including Nicole Kidman for supporting actress and for the first time in Oscar history an Australian film, the remarkable Tanna, was nominated for best foreign language film. 
Australian Oscar newcomer Jason Billington, for his visual effects work on oil rig disaster film Deepwater Horizon, also scored an invite to Hollywood's biggest night. 
The ceremony, however, is expected to be dominated by the quintessential Los Angeles movie, the musical La La Land which has 14 nominations - equalling the all-time Oscar record held by Titanic and All About Eve. 
Gibson's nomination was significant because for the past decade the industry has shunned him for alleged anti-Semitic, sexist and racial rants and domestic abuse while he struggled with alcoholism 
The Academy is not some club of faceless people. 
It is made up of 7000 of the most famous people on the planet. 
They are Gibson's peers. 
Tom Hanks, Meryl Streep, Steven Spielberg, Martin Scorsese, Nicole Kidman, Cate Blanchett, Naomi Watts, Russell Crowe - pretty much anyone who has won an Oscar, received multiple nominations or has had an influential role in Hollywood is likely a member. 
The Academy this year also had plenty of other compelling directing options to nominate instead of Gibson. 
A-List directors who missed out include Denzel Washington (Fences), Scorsese (Silence), Clint Eastwood (Sully) and Tom Ford (Nocturnal Animals). 
Gibson will compete with La La Land's Damien Chazelle, the favourite, and Moonlight's Barry Jenkins, Arrival's Denis Villeneuve and Manchester By the Sea's Kenneth Lonergan. 
"It has been an especially difficult environment for Mel, but to come all of the way back and get that from all of his peers, he is walking on air," Mechanic said. 
Since his nomination Hollywood studios have been courting Gibson with major projects, including Warner Bros reportedly hoping he would direct Suicide Squad 2. 
Last year, largely on the back of George Miller's Mad Max: Fury Road, Australia had a record Oscar haul with 13 nominations and eight wins. 
This year Australia's best chances are Hacksaw Ridge's sound editors Andy Wright and Robert Mackenzie. 
Wright and Mackenzie, along with another Aussie Peter Grace and American Kevin O'Connell, are also decent chances of winning the sound mixing Oscar for Hacksaw Ridge. 
O'Connell has the infamous title of being the most nominated person in Academy Awards' history never to win, with Hacksaw Ridge his 21st nod and his painfully long list of misses dating back to Terms of Endearment in 1984. 
Wright laughed when AAP asked him if he might jump in front of the microphone and rob O'Connell of an acceptance speech if they finally win. 
"Oh no," Wright said. 
"I'll be happy to stand back and let him speak." 
Donald Trump is expected to be the elephant in the Dolby Theatre, with winners venting about the US president, particularly when the foreign language film Oscar is announced. 
Tanna's Australian filmmakers Bentley Dean and Martin Butler penned a joint letter with the other four filmmakers nominated in the category blasting Trump's attempted travel ban directed against seven mostly Muslim nations, including Iran. 
The Iranian director of the category favourite, The Salesman, will not attend the ceremony in protest of Trump. 
In another controversial incident, Khaled Khateeb, a 21-year-old Syrian cinematographer who worked on the nominated documentary short, The White Helmets, was barred entry into the US after officials reportedly found "derogatory information" on him. 
Dean and Butler will be joined on the red carpet and in the Dolby Theatre by two of their stars, Selin Kawia and Lingai Kawia, and interpreter JJ Nako, who will be wearing their traditional dress from the tiny Vanuatu volcanic island of Tanna. 
The men will be shirtless and wear large vertical penis sheaths. 
AUSTRALIA'S 2017 OSCAR NOMINEES 
Mel Gibson - directing (Hacksaw Ridge) 
Andy Wright, Robert Mackenzie, Peter Grace - sound mixing (Hacksaw Ridge) 
Andy Wright, Robert Mackenzie - sound editing (Hacksaw Ridge) 
Nicole Kidman - supporting actress (Lion) 
Emile Sherman, Angie Fielder - best picture (Lion) 
Luke Davies - adapted screenplay (Lion) 
Greig Fraser - cinematography (Lion) 
Bentley Dean, Martin Butler - foreign language film (Tanna)
